title: BYO Cloud: Iron Mountain CIO Comes With G Suite
text:
When Kim Anstett left Nielsen Holdings PLC in April to become Iron Mountain Inc. ’s chief information officer, she took some favorite items with her: cloud-computing, productivity and collaboration tools developed by Alphabet Inc. ’s Google.

Ms. Anstett, who was Nielsen’s CIO for five years, said G Suite proved so effective at the data and television-ratings giant that she plans to roll it out at Iron Mountain in the months ahead—replacing the document-storage company’s use of on-premise Microsoft Corp. apps.

Kim Anstett, Iron Mountain's chief information officer. Photo: FayFoto Boston

Sticking with tried-and-true business applications might seem like an easy decision for information-technology leaders, even as they switch companies or industries. The average tenure of a CIO is roughly four years at one company, according to executive search firm Korn Ferry.

But the approach can come with unexpected risks, analysts say. Being too loyal to a tech partner can reduce a company’s flexibility to pivot as technology, markets or business models change. By being too wedded to certain tools, CIOs can miss out on new ones or on lower prices for similar applications.

Tech tools that worked well at one company aren’t always the right fit for another, said Stephanie Stoudt-Hansen, a senior research director at research and advisory firm Gartner Inc.

Steven Capper, CIO at Netherlands-based construction company BAM Groep NV, said he prefers to go with trusted vendors “that you have used and can rely on,” adding, “The main role of a CIO is to ensure that IT works. It makes sense to use your own playbook.”

Vendor relationships “often travel together,” especially when they have developed into long-term partnerships, said Steve Bates, who leads the CIO Center of Excellence at accounting firm KPMG LLP.

Part of Google’s strategy in the enterprise IT space has been to foster these kinds of partnerships with CIOs, in part by building up customer services and working with companies on solving business problems, Thomas Kurian, Google Cloud’s chief executive, told CIOs this month at the Gartner IT Symposium/Xpo in Orlando.

Ms. Anstett agrees there is no one-size-fits-all in enterprise IT: “The last thing any company wants is some external tech leader to come in with all the answers,” she said.

The Iron Mountain CIO said she is working with the Boston-based company’s business divisions to help prepare its 25,000 workers for the switch to G Suite. Feedback from a 30-person implementation team will be used to make tweaks in the strategy ahead of the rollout, which she said she expects to be complete within seven months.

Write to Angus Loten at angus.loten@wsj.com
description: Kim Anstett liked Google’s cloud tools so much while CIO at Nielsen that she decided to roll them out at document-storage company Iron Mountain.
